comment.text: Rapid intensification happens…rapidly. Well, yes it does. Also, I think where it makes landfall is a $billion question. Loading...
Sure need some rain. When is our next chance for some precipitation? Loading...
Great question. We don’t see it coming over the next 7-10 days, and nothing stands out beyond that right now. This has been the story of this long La Niña: Long stretches of dryness punctuated...
We need rain! Where is our rain? Loading...
If the storm were going to affect Paris, we’d still have several of the nervous colon types wondering when Houstonians should evacuate. Loading...
I have a 70-year old family member scheduled to fly from IAH to Miami on Wednesday afternoon. Do you think air travel to Miami gets disrupted Wednesday PM? Loading...
One thing we can’t predict is what airlines will do. There’s certainly a chance it will be disrupted, even if Miami is not expected to see significant impacts. But that’s about all we...
What is keeping Ian from intensifying right now? It was looking healthy yesterday, then the thunderstorms near the center just died. Why? Loading...
Thanks for taking the time out of your weekend for this update!! You guys rock. Loading...

title: NOAA Historical Hurricane Tracks
snippet: global image showing historic hurricane landfalls ... here: Category 4 and 5 hurricane tracks that crossed over the state of Florida between 1910 and 2018.
htmlSnippet: global image showing historic hurricane landfalls ... here: Category 4 and 5 hurricane tracks that crossed over the state of Florida between 1910 and 2018.

metatags.dc.description: NOAA's Historical Hurricane Tracks is a free online tool that allows users to track historic hurricane tracks. The site, developed by the NOAA Office for Coastal Management in partnership with NOAA's National Hurricane Center and National Centers for Environmental Information, offers data and information on coastal county hurricane strikes through 2012. It also provides links to detailed reports on the life histories and effects of U.S. tropical cyclones since 1958, with additional U.S. storm paths traced as far back as 1851. The site contains global hurricane data from as far back as 1842.
metatags.dc.creator: US Department of Commerce, National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration
metatags.og:title: NOAA Historical Hurricane Tracks
